title: £15m investment for rural development
story: OVER poundm has been invested in a number of projects across the Newry, Mourne and Down Council area with funding provided under the Rural Development Programme.The cash was administered by the Mourne, Gullion and Lecale Rural Development Partnership with the Leader Programmersquos village renewal money supporting  projects, including the development or refurbishment of  community facilities, benefiting over , people.Stormont rural affairs minister Edwin Poots attended a recent event at Killeavy Castle in Newry to celebrate the success in delivering his Departmentrsquos programme which also created  new jobs.He congratulated members of the Mourne, Gullion and Lecale Rural Development Partnership for their work in delivering the programme, supporting village renewal and improving infrastructure.The minister also referenced his recent statement to the Assembly regarding Northern Irelandrsquos first ever rural policy framework.ldquoI want to create a new programme going forward that will be completely tailored to our own unique circumstances in Northern Ireland, he explained.ldquoThe framework will see a new rural business and community investment programme that will cover the next seven years and will support my Departmentrsquos vision of putting sustainability at the heart of a living, working, active landscape valued by everyone.In addition, Mr Poots said the new framework will also demonstrate his Departmentrsquos ongoing commitment to ensuring that rural communities flourish and prosper through continued support and investment in initiatives that will make a tangible dference to those living and working in rural areas.Cllr Roisin Mulgrew, chairwoman of the Mourne, Gullion and Lecale Partnership, said the delivery of the programme has brought ldquosignicant benefits to the rural dwellers of Newry, Mourne and Down and is testament to the dedication of the Local Action Group.She added: ldquoThe knowledge of the members has ensured projects of high quality have been supported, which have positively impacted on the lives of the rural dwellers.Council chairwoman, Cathy Mason, said the organisation, in partnership with the Local Action Group and Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs, has been extremely successful in the delivery of the Leader programme.ldquoThe positive impacts have ensured a strong rural economy, providing dwellers with access to high quality community facilities, towns and villages they can be proud to call home, she added..prettyPhoto

title: Ambitious plans for Camino style walk  in Down District
story: AMBITIOUS plans for a major walking trail which passes through Down District have received a pound, boost.A key component of the planned Columban Way is to develop ldquopilgrimage walking such as that found at Spainrsquos Camino de Santiago and at many other trails across Europe, with the trail highlighting Northern Irelandrsquos ancient heritage, including major Neolithic and early Christian sites along the way.It has been confirmed that a pound, grant has made available by the David Cross Foundation to produce a business case with costings to identy and develop the Columban Way from Dundrum to the Saint Patrickrsquos Centre in Downpatrick and from there to Comber by repurposing and upgrading sections of the former Ulster Way which was abandoned in the s.St Columbanus was one of the best-known of hundreds of Irish monks following in the footsteps of Saint Patrick in bringing Christianity, literacy and learning to Central and Northern Europe in the sixth century.Downpatrick councillor Cadogan Enright mdash who is an enthusiastic supporter of the new trail mdash said ii took St Columbanus  years to complete the journey from Bangor to Bobbio in Italy and he travelled more than , miles, mostly on foot.He is leading the local aspect of the project alongside Charlie Reid from Bangor, with both writing extensively on walks around Ireland and are committee members of Friends of Columbanus. They are supported by Duane Fitzsimons, from Ardglass, who is a walking trails expert.ldquoThe Columban Way forms part of the wider European lsquoVia Columbanirsquo heritage trail supported and promoted by the Council of Europe. It traces the route from Mount Leinster to Bangor through eight European countries to Bobbio in Italy, explained Cllr Enright.ldquoIt is instructive to see how rapidly other countries have rolled out sections of the trail since  and the th anniversary of Columbanus. Switzerland, Italy, France, Germany and the Low Countries have demonstrated the ability to deliver that we can learn from locally.Cllr Enright praised the support of Ards and North Down Council which has already delivered  miles of walk as far south as Comber.ldquoThis -mile section of trail is designed to encourage more people to learn about the history of North Down and Ards, including the impact the area had in a European context through the links with Columbanus, he explained.ldquoOur big challenge will be to engage with Newry Mourne and Down Council to deal with their huge gaps in the Saint Patrickrsquos and Ulster Ways. These should link Downpatrick to Dundrum and Killyleagh, but still have not yet done so..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch Women win yet again
story: BALLYNAHINCH continue their pursuit of a domestic double when they travel to Armagh on Saturday in the quarter-finals of the Senior Cup.Ballynahinch Women followed up their win over leaders Carrickfergus with a hard fought - victory over derby rivals Lisburn.The teams shared six tries with a lone Jane Patton conversion proving the dference between the sides on a dficult surface.Veteran centre Rachel Morton weighed in with two tries and Avril Sherlock was the other try scorer.Coach Sara Simms and her team will be pleased with the rate of improvement shown and will hope to keep pushing up the table during the final part of the season.The seconds continue to blood young players during their Second XV League campaign and had another emphatic home win on Saturday.Armagh were on the end of a five tries to one defeat and coach Davy Harris will have been pleased with the response his team have shown since their Townsrsquo Cup defeat at the end of February.James Martin, Matthew Cooper, Ben McMullan, Cameron McGaughey and Harry McCormick were the try scorers.Injuries and call-ups to the first XV squad have had an impact and there will be opportunities for young players to stake a claim for a place in the senior squad next season over the next few weeks.Marty OrsquoNeillrsquos fourth XV continued their red-hot  form with an excellent - victory over Harlequins thirds.They have a % record in their league section and face a crucial three-week period with home and away fixtures against nearest rivals Academy either side of a Forster Plate semi-final against Donegal Town.A fth XV squad with an average age of  travelled to Banbridge on Friday night and came home with a superb - victory.Tiernan Keating, Conor Spence and Sam Forbes made their senior debuts and  players had appeared at some stage this season for the club Academy side.They have three consecutive home games coming up, including a home semi-final in the McCambley Cup against Ballymena fourths.Youth training continues at pm on Monday nights. Contact Michael Preston for details on  .Mini rugby continues on Saturday mornings from .-am. Boys and girls from P to Year  are all welcome, with training run for each age group in their school year.Mini rugby news is posted weekly on the club Facebook page: www.facebook ballynahinchrfcofficial. For more details contact David Martin on   or email hinchminis@gmail.Details of how to purchase a full selection of Hinch merchandise can be found on our social media outlets and on the club app.AIL pre-match lunches are back in full swing with Dublin University the visitors on March . Contact James Shaw on  , Erin Hodgen on  , or David George on  .Results: Ballynahinch II  Omagh II  , Ballynahinch IV  Harlequins III  , Banbridge VI  Ballynahinch V  , Lisburn Women  Ballynahinch Women  .Fixtures: Armagh v Ballynahinch , Ballynahinch III v Dungannon II , Ballynahinch IV v Academy II , Ballynahinch V v Newry II ..prettyPhoto

title: Clock is ticking on  Shrigley landmark
story: SHRIGLEYrsquoS historic clock could be restored as part of an ambitious redevelopment plan for the village, it has been revealed.The Housing Executive mdash owners of the monument which has been in a rundown state for decades mdash are in talks with a local interest group in relation to compiling a feasibility study to examine options and prepare design concepts for the area which would involve the acquisition and restoration of the Martin Memorial clock.Various calls have made over many decades for the Victorian clock to be restored to its former glory but no progress has been made. But that could be about to change.Last year, the estimated repair bill for the clock, whose interior mechanism was removed over three decades ago and placed in storage, was in the region of pound,.Many are concerned to see the historic landmark falling into continued disrepair, but hopeful that it can be restored to be enjoyed for generations to come, reinforcing its connection with the villagersquos industrial past.Shrigley was founded by the Martin family, who came from Pott Shrigley in Cheshire in  and who owned the spinning factory in the village.The factory was powered by water supplied from the nearby Clea Lough and while the mill mdash which is reported to have employed  people at one time mdash has long gone, the clock tower erected by the people of Shrigley in  in honour of the Martin family remains.Now there is fresh hope that it can be restored to its former glory.Strangford MLAs Michelle McIlveen and Harry Harvey, who have been campaigning for the clockrsquos restoration, are also hopeful that progress can be made.Welcoming the recent developments, they hope plans to acquire the clock and restore it to its former glory will prove successful.The MLAs said Housing Executive chief executive Grainia Long made it clear last year that the huge cost of repairing the historic clock was something the organisation was not willing to meet at the time.The housing chief said at a time when it was experiencing a signicant funding shortfall for investment in tenantsrsquo homes, it was not be appropriate to use income derived from rents to fund the considerable costs that would be required to undertake a full restoration of the Shrigley clock.Ms McIlveen and Mr Harvey then raised the issue with Stormont communities minister Deirdre Hargey, who has overall responsibility for the Historical Environment Division.They detailed the clockrsquos history and its local signicance, explaining that it is one of the last remaining pieces of Victorian architecture in Shrigley.The MLAs said it was ldquounacceptable that an old clock of such important signicance and splendour should be allowed to fall into such a sad state of disrepair.ldquoWe urged the communities minister to take the necessary steps to prevent this important listed monument from further deterioration and urged her to consider a partnership approach with ious interested bodies, explained Ms McIlveen.ldquoI am pleased that the Housing Executive is now in discussions with an interested local party regarding a proposed feasibility study to consider options and prepare design concepts for the area that would involve the acquisition and restoration of the historic monument.Ms McIlveen said discussions are ongoing and that she and Mr Harvey have made clear to the government department and Housing Executive their desire that these discussions should be centred on the interests of the Shirley community, with the outcome safeguarding the future of the cherished monument..prettyPhoto

title: Council set to review museum joint curator restructure role
story: THE controversial decision to restructure the districtrsquos museum services is to be reviewed.Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos decision to appoint a joint curator to oversee museum services in Downpatrick and Newry mdash which was taken without consulting local councillors mdash is to be reviewed by the local authorityrsquos Audit Committee.The newly appointed curator will be based in Newry, a move which has angered a number of councillors and highly respected organisations, including the Friends of the Down County Museum.Council officials have been accused of downgrading the status of the Downpatrick museum with stinging criticism continuing of the decision to have one curator in charge of the local authorityrsquos two museums.Council officials insist they are ldquofully committed to the continuous improvement and development of both museums and that updated staffing structures for both ldquoprovides an unparalleled opportunity to build in this work.The restructuring process has been referred to the Audit Committee by Downpatrick councillor Gareth Sharvin, who is disappointed that despite signicant opposition to the move, the new joint curator is already in post.He wants the process which led to the councilrsquos decision to be reviewed, with the referral coming on the back of an update on the new staffing structure recently provided in secret to members of the local authorityrsquos Strategy, Policy and Resources Committee.Cllr Sharvin said while the press and public were prevented from hearing the update, he understands that the new curator will be based in Newry and shared across both museum sites.He continued: ldquoThe new staff structure is seen as an activity under the so-called scheme of delegation that enables the councilrsquos senior management team to conduct the change without the need to consult or inform any stakeholders in the process.ldquoThe new staff structure is currently being implemented and cannot be subject to change, as the roles have been offered out. We are told this is an operational matter that councillors are not involved in.Cllr Sharvin says he is disappointed to have to confirm that the new staff structure will be implemented at Down County Museum, which means it will have no permanent curator in the building.ldquoGiven the lack of information around the new roles and how the existing complement of skills are being integrated into the new museum structure, it can only raise concern as no one outside the senior management team have the information and understanding of how the fantastic services provided in Downpatrick will continue to be offered and delivered, he continued.ldquoThe campaign by the Friends of the Museum and the many groups associated with the Down County Museum was very much focused on the skills needed to run the museum and offer the excellent experience many hundreds of thousands of people have enjoyed over the years.Cllr Sharvin insists that a strategic review should have been undertaken first to understand the vision for the museum services in the district, design a plan around that vision and identy the staffing structure needed to support it.ldquoWhat has happened in this case, is that the staff structure is being implemented and a strategic review being held afterwards. The strategic review could easily identy that a dferent staffing structure is needed as opposed to the one being implemented now, he continued.ldquoI want to see the Down County Museum grow in size, reputation and service offerings. When you research the top  museums in Northern Ireland on Which Museum, the Downpatrick museum is placed th compared to Newry which is st.ldquoSimilarly on TripAdvisor, the Downpatrick museum is listed th, with Newry in th place. This shows a clear dference in status for each museum and where the councilrsquos main museum asset is.Councillor Sharvin explained he has referred the museum process and procedure to the councilrsquos Audit Committee for a number of reasons, even though he accepts the review will have no signicance in relation to the staffing structure as that will continue.However, he said the move will ensure that ldquolessons are learnt for any future changes and the Downpatrick museum is protected and respected.Cllr Sharvin explained the role of the audit committee is to review internal procedures and that is what he has asked to be examined.ldquoThere is no clear one approach when it comes to restructuring in council and the review of the procedures undertaken in this case will help the organisation identy were gaps are, what risks have been identied and the improvements that need to be implemented, he said.Cllr Sharvin said he has asked for a timeline of the start and completion of the strategic review being implemented and how key stakeholders such as the Friends of the Museum will be consulted as part of the process.He added: ldquoThe strategic review is now the focus of the campaign to ensure that the Down County Museum is not downgraded in any way. I will be approaching the strategic review with the sense of growth in visitor numbers, educational outreach, advertising campaigns, collection and exhibition offerings and the wider service offerings..prettyPhoto

title: Dawn launches debut novel
story: THE debut novel by a local childrenrsquos writer is already one of the top selling books in its age category on Amazon.Felicity Flipflops is the work of Dawn Gelston, a teacher living in Dubai but who has strong links with Drumaness and Teconnaught.She is the daughter of Paul and Maura Gelston and sister to Shona, Aisling, Janine and Paul.Aimed at children aged  to  years old, the book tells the story of mental well-being, adventure, and friendship by a young girl named Felicity.Dawn explained: ldquoAs teachers, we encourage children to believe in themselves and to work hard and dream big. The book is funny and heart-warming, underpinned with elements of emotional well-being for children mdash something which is so important.ldquoI hope that children, and their families, read and enjoy the book and understand that we should be ourselves and itrsquos OK to be a little bit dferent.Her love and respect for home has inspired her first book as she has dedicated it to her primary school teacher, the late Leo Flanagan, former principal of Christ the King Primary School, Drumaness, and St Patrickrsquos Primary School, Ballynahinch.ldquoMr Flanagan was a one-of-a-kind teacher and a very inspirational leader. He taught me confidence, how to believe in myself, and encouraged me to do what I love. Even thirty years after I have left primary school, hersquos had a huge impact on me and given me the courage to go for it.Dawn plans to be home in a few weeksrsquo time and is hoping to visit as many schools as possible to share her book with local pupils.The book has already made it to number two and number four in some best selling categories on Amazon and is receiving rave reviews online.She said: ldquoI am overwhelmed by the amount of support I have received from my friends, family, and the local community, and want to thank everyone for their well wishes.ldquoI hope you enjoy getting to know Felicity Flopflops, as much as I have enjoyed creating the character and writing her story.Felicity Flipflops costs pound. in paperback or pound. for the kindle edition on Amazon..prettyPhoto

title: Delight Newcastle centre plans  in final stages before publication
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council has been urged to do all it can to quickly deliver Newcastlersquos new multi-million pound leisure complex.The appeal was issued by the local authorityrsquos chairwoman, Cathy Mason, following a recent meeting she had with senior council directors who provided her with a progress report.A detailed report on building the eagerly-awaited pound leisure centre is expected to be completed shortly, with senior council officials working with consultants to develop an outline business case which is designed to pave the way for construction work to start.The rear of the existing Newcastle Centre and the outdoor Tropicana swimming pool are to be bulldozed to make way for the new town centre leisure complex which will feature an indoor leisure pool which includes three  metre swimming lanes and a dedicated heated play pool for children.The new leisure facility will also feature an ultra-modern gymnasium and once demolition work has been completed, the new complex will be bolted on to the side of the existing centre.Redeveloping the existing Newcastle Centre has been ruled out due to the scale of the costs involved and itrsquos understood that the planned new-build will be larger than the current centre which is a listed building, posing major problems for the council in transforming it into an energy efficient facility which meets current building regulations and standards.Cllr Mason described confirmation of plans for new leisure facilities in Newcastle as ldquowelcome news and is delighted that the development plans are in the final stages of development.ldquoThese new local amenities will be of great benefit to local residents, their families and tourists alike, she said, confirming that the proposes new complex will feature a new leisure pool and state of the art gym facilities.ldquoFor too long, people of Newcastle have had to put up with these substandard facilities, the chairwoman continued. ldquoThe plans highlighted safety concerns with the old part of the building which is to be demolished as it simply isnrsquot fit for purpose.Cllr Mason said she hopes to see the finalised plans and formal site approval in the coming months so that contractors can start working on the project as soon as possible.ldquoIt is essential that the council moves in a timely manner to ensure this project comes to fruition so that Newcastle residents can access these new facilities as soon as possible, said the chairwoman.ldquoSinn Feacutein will continue to do all it can to ensure these much-needed leisure facilities are delivered and I will continue to stand up for rural families across South Down to deliver these essential services right in the heart of communities.Last week, formal planning approval to bulldoze the rear extension of the existing Newcastle Centre and the adjoining Tropicana swimming pool was agreed by the local authorityrsquos Planning Committee.Detailed work has already been carried out at the town centre site, including geotechnical surveys which examined ground conditions to provide architects and designers with key information ahead of construction work getting underway.While no detailed timescales are in place, politicians hope that major progress to deliver the project can now be made, with planning permission and all other associated approvals secured in a timely fashion..prettyPhoto

title: Fin tasic with formation of new angling club
story: A NEW course angling club has been formed in Downpatrick.Known as Quoile Angling Club, the organisation is holding its inaugural meeting this Friday night at Murphyrsquos Bar in the town at pm, with an open invitation extended to anyone who would like to attend.The club was formed in response to the growing interest in course angling at the river and with coronavirus restrictions largely gone, anglers have joined forces to form the new club and aim to encourage greater involvement in angling, particularly for coarse fish in the lower reaches of the River Quoile.The picturesque river is home to rudd, roach, hybrids, bream, pike, and eels.The new club is hoping to run a few competitions and, in the future, provide coaching courses for young anglers.A key concern for the new club is addressing the current state of the fishery which runs from the below the Belfast Road bridge to the Steamboat quay.The aim is to engage with a raft of statutory agencies to raise the profile of the river and its angling potential, alongside improved access for anglers and visitors.While there has been signicant investment over recent years and additional upgrades in the pipeline, the anglers will hope this paves the way for greater emphasis on the Quoile area as a recreational and tourism asset.Anglers say the Quoile basin is a designated nature reserve and, as such, there are ious regulations which govern its usage, with those who fish along its banks keen to maintain the waterwayrsquos biological ersity and general appearance, ensuring it is an asset everyone can enjoy.At the clubrsquos inaugural meeting this Friday evening, members will adopt a constitution and select a new management committee. The meeting in Murphyrsquos Bar will be chaired by local councillor Oonagh Hanlon..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C  March 18%2C 1992
story: DOWNPATRICK ndash Work begins this week on the first stages of the pound.m investment package which has been unveiled to help regenerate the economic and environmental fortunes of Downpatrick.The massive investment for the town will include a major new traffic filter road, environmental improvements and two separate community-led economic schemes.It is the first phase of a package which may be expanded to include a major new tourist facility to help develop Downpatrick and Lecale as an international tourist destination.The details were announced by Economy Minister, Mr Richard Needham, and the chairman of the International Fund for Ireland, Mr John B McGuckian, at a special conference in the townrsquos Down County Museum on Friday,The conference chairman, the South Down MP Mr Eddie McGrady, said the package represents ldquoa carefully planned and structured regeneration of Downpatrick.Mr Needham said: ldquoThis package is vital for the future of Downpatrick which has an enormous tourist potential. The funding provided by the Department means it will be assisting Downpatrick in a very substantive way over the next few years.ldquoThe planning has been completed. The next stage is to get things done. I know the partnership between the public, private and voluntary sectors which has developed here will moved forward to a successful conclusion and soon we will all see a major improvement in the appearance and le of Downpatrick, added the Minister.A new town centre plan was unveiled at the conference, together with a design guide to compliment the objectives of the Downpatrick conservation area.DUNDRUM ndash Pupils at two Dundrum schools, damaged by fire just before Christmas, have benefited from the Down Leisure Centrersquos annual fund-raising drive.Downshire and the Sacred Heart primary schools are the recipients of pound, which will go towards replacing equipment which was destroyed in two malicious fires in December.The money represents a record total of all leisure centre staff who organise a charity event each year. Past beneficiaries include Children in Need, the Ethiopian Appeal and local children who received toys.This yearrsquos total is a record figure for the centre staff who used their spare time to organised a sponsored swim for the schools.Both schools attended the centrersquos Schools Swimming Programme together and when the teachers and the young children related their plight to the swimming teachers the staff decided to help.The result was an organised sponsored swim with all the schools in the swimming programme taking part and all raising money. Down Councilrsquos community relations department gave full backing to the event by giving the centre facilities free of charge.BALLYNAHINCH ndash An offer of  per cent funding has been made by the Department of the Environment towards the costs of bringing the Fair Green in Ballynahinch into public ownership.Details of the offer to Down District Council were revealed this week by local SDLP MP, Mr Eddie McGrady.He said: ldquoThe Department has also agreed, in principle, to grant aid the environmental improvement of the area, subject to the availability of funds.ldquoDown District Council is presently in discussion with consultants with regard to the preparation of a suitable scheme of environmental improvement.The South Down MP added: ldquoI would like to see this scheme proceed at Fair Green. This should be one component in an overall regeneration strategy for Ballynahich.NEWCASTLE ndash An ldquoexciting initiative in telecommunications, the first of its kind in Northern Ireland, was officially unveiled in Newcastle this week.The Burrendale STAR Project, which offers the only video conferencing facility in the Province, was launched on Monday morning with an impressive link up between two sites in Newcastle and another in England.The European Community sponsored project is run by Newcastle College of Further Education in conjunction with the Burrendale Hotel where the conferencing facility is based.It uses advanced fibre-optic telecommunications lines, which circle Northern Ireland, to allow conference organisers to visually link-up with similar facilities anywhere in the world.In means guest speakers no longer have to travel to a conference but need only go to the nearest video facility to take full part in a meeting being held thousands of miles away.So advanced is this form of communications system that plans to link up with Boston at Mondayrsquos launch had to be shelved when it was discovered the prominent American city does not yet have the appropriate technology.The Burrendale video conferencing facility, which was set up under STAR, which stands for Special Telecommunications Action for Regional Development, comprises two complete sets of video and sound equipment to enable the project to supply both ends of the video conferencing linknecessary.ARDGLASS ndash The Ardglass fishing fleet is prepared to co-operate fullya worthwhile decommissioning scheme is introduced for the industry, it has been stressed this week.As many as six vessels would be taken out of the Ardglass fleet of the Government provides a proper compensation scheme to help fishermen get out of the industry.The figures were given when South Down MP, Mr Eddie McGrady, met with fishermensrsquo representatives in the village last week.The MP was urged by Mr Dick James, chief executive of the Northern Ireland Fish Producers Organisation, to apply the maximum political pressure on the issue.Mr James was joined at the meeting by some of those who would be prepared to take advantage of a decommissioning scheme, including Mr Frank Zych and Mr Rod Harding.The fishermen complained that the recent decommissioning scheme announced by the Government will not help reduce the UK fleet or with the conservation of fish stocks.BISHOPSCOURT ndash Bishopscourt residents are claiming that events surrounding Saturdayrsquos inaugural motor-cycle meeting had justied their protest campaign against racing at the former RAF base.Several local residents have complained bitterly about noise levels coming from the track and of non-stop traffic in the area throughout the day.They say the situation will get worse when meetings are held during the summer and they are calling on the Planning Service to refuse permission for further development of the track.One of the protestors, local farmer Joseph Fitzsimons said: ldquoSome of our worst fears were realised on Saturday.Mr Fitzsimons said continuous traffic on the main road to the airfield prevented him from moving some of his stock.ldquoWe had non-stop traffic from . am until pm. I had intended moving some sheep but it proved to be impossible, he remarked.CASTLEWELLAN ndash A discussion on possible sculpture schemes for the Downpatrick and Castlewellan areas will be held in Castlewellan library next Monday evening.Members of the Sculptorsrsquo Society of Ireland will be present at the meeting to give a brief slide show and talk on the range of possibilities for public sculptures and the procedures for commissioning them.Society members will also talk about how sculptors can be used for educational schemes involving adults and children, and there will be a display of work by sculptors form Down District.KILLYLEAGH ndash The Department of the Environment will put Killyleagh forward as a possible location for the new Strangford Lough Liaison Office, a Government Minister has said this week.Environment Minister, Mr Richard Needham, has told South Down SDLP MP, Mr Eddie McGrady, that the idea of siting the office in Killyleagh will be put forward by the Department, although a final decision is up to the new lough committee.Meanwhile, Down District Council has agreed to pay . per cent of the costs of the Strangford Lough liaison officer and office on condition that it is given equal representation to Ards Borough Council on the new management committee. Down has been offered two places to Ardsrsquothree on the new committee..prettyPhoto

title: Greer leads the line again
story: CARRYDUFFrsquoS Jonny Greer and co-driver Darragh Mullen secured victory in the Race and Rally Stages, second round of the McGrady Insurance Northern Ireland Rally Championship at the weekend.Held at Bishopscourt Race Circuit and organised by Ballynahinch and District Motor Club, Greer dominated the six-stage event from start to finish. He was inch-perfect through the morningrsquos slippery conditions, quickly building up a sizeable advantage and catching his rivals on the hop.This continued his fine form after the local driver also won the opening stages.In the space of two stages, he had amassed a lead of more than  seconds ndash a huge margin on the single venue event.From there, he managed his lead and with the sun shining, Greer powered home in his Citroen C to eventually win by . seconds and claim another maximum points haul in his bid for this yearrsquos championship spoils.ldquoIt was a brilliant day, said Greer.ldquoThe car was faultless and was really well suited to the event. We kept it clean and everything went to plan.In the battle for second overall, Derek McGarrity and Graham Henderson held an early second in their Skoda until a stage two overshoot cost them around ten seconds.Aaron McLaughlin and Darren Curran also hit trouble with a puncture and a broken rim, while Darren Gass and Sam Hutchinson were already out of contention after they spun and stalled on stage one.That left McGarrity and McLaughlin battling for the runner-up spot. McLaughlin quickly recovered from his puncture and moved into second after stage three. McGarrity tried hard to fight back but in the drying conditions, McLaughlin had the edge in his Fiesta WRC.He was really enjoying himself and an attempt to secure the fastest time on the final stage saw him come to within one-tenth of a second of rally winner Greer.ldquoHersquos a machine, said McLaughlin.ldquoI was really hoping for a fastest stage time. I just wish we had started the day as good as we finished it.Derek McGarrity and Graham Henderson had to be content with third overall in their Skoda. Their stage two overshoot potentially cost them a position but they still secured an armful of points for their McGrady Insurance NI Championship campaign.ldquoIt was a silly mistake on the second stage, said McGarrity.ldquoThen we had a small misfire on the last stage but it is what it is.Joe McGonigle and Ciaran Geaney clipped a bale and damaged the front wing of their Fiesta on stage two but they survived to tell the tale.Seventh after the test, they climbed back up the order to secure fourth overall ahead of Joe and Ashleen Hegarty, who were lucky to escape a high-speed spin on stage four.ldquoWe were using new tyres and the car broke away from me at high speed, explained Hegarty.ldquoWe went over a few trackside tyres and ended up on the grass.Darren Gass and Sam Hutchinson would have been in the mix too but they took a wrong route on stage five and were handed a stage maximum. Instead, Michael McGarrity and Damien Garvey were overjoyed to claim sixth overall in their Fiesta.They lost time when a boost pipe came adrt and also struggled with some brakingissues during the closing miles but were full of smiles at the finish.Also in a Fiesta, David Kelly and Dean OrsquoSullivan finished seventh ahead of Mark Massey and Alistair Wyllie.Massey was lucky to escape with some superficial bodywork damage after a stage five altercation with some trackside stage furniture so a top eight finish was a good result for the crew.Emma McKinstry and Kenny Hull lost time with some intercom issues but finished ninth while Robert Erwin and Andrew Wilson completed the top ten and secured the two-wheel-drive honours in the process.In the two-wheel-drive category, a titanic battle developed between a number of crews. James and Heather Kennedy were quickest out of the blocks, closely followed by Andrew White and Paul Hughes.Then White lost ground with an overshoot, leaving Kennedy to fend off a challenge from Robert Erwin and Andrew Wilson.As the track conditions improved, Erwin started to pile the pressure on the Kennedys who were suffering with a down-on-power engine.The chasing Toyota MR crew moved in front after the fth test and another strong run over the final stage sealed the category win as well as tenth overall.James and Heather Kennedy had to settle for second on this occasion as well as th overall, with Matthew McGaffin and Ryan Lowry coming home third in class.The McGrady Insurance NI Rally Championship now has a two-month break before the Maiden City Stages on May .In the interim period, a rally social night is being held at the Millbrook Lodge Hotel on Friday, March . The evening includes a rally show featuring competitor interviews, live music, the  Championship awards presentation and other entertainment.All rally fans are encouraged to attend. Tickets are freeand are available from rallyscore.net. For more information, see nirallychampionship..prettyPhoto

title: Jimmy’s Ten returns to streets of Downpatrick
story: JIMMYrsquoS TEN is hosted annually by East Down AC in memory of Jimmy Murray for his devotion to the sport and is usually tied in with the St Patrickrsquos Day festivities in the town of Downpatrick.In , Covid- called a halt and no race was held at all. In  it was decided to move both date and venue to have the best chance of fitting in with Covid- restrictions.While the event at Bishopscourt Racing Circuit last June was well received, many were glad to see the race brought back to its origins as a road race taking in the iconic sites of East Downrsquos home town.Months of planning go into a race and this year was no exception. The EDAC race committee had an A and B routes on file in case of flooding on the Quoile towpath.They had worked with and through Covid- restrictions, secured road licences and Athletics NI permits, and employed professionals for timing, first aid and traffic management among others.The club rallied members and friends of the club to marshal the roads, man the water station and prepare the post race food tables.The race committee were out at am on Sunday to finalise the cones and signage when news broke that a fallen tree had brought down a power line directly impacting the planned route.East Down AC volunteers were straight into action. They were at the scene in minutes and had even a tree surgeon on speed dial, but they could not gain access.They were determined not to cancel and set about re-routing the race. This is not as simple as it may seem. With a traffic management plan to take into account and new sections to measure as well as the clock ticking, there was a lot of pressure.The wind and rain didnrsquot help and mindful of the wellbeing of runners, a delayed start was not even considered.With some sharp thinking and speedy manoeuvres a new route was hurriedly drawn up.Having advised the athletes that it was no longer a measured K, the start team herded them on to the start line in Ballydugan Estate and the hooter went only a minute or two behind schedule.With a huge sigh of relief Mags Mathieson, the official starter, waved the  strong crowd on their way. Thankfully everything  went to plan and post race comments have been nothing but positive from those who took part.There was high praise for the volunteers along the route, who cheered, clapped and gave out water. It was not the race that East Down AC had planned but with  fresh in our memories, most were simply glad that they got the chance to run.With all that had gone on pre-race there was barely time to consider who the winner might be, but there was a wave of excitement when Neil McCartan of East Down appeared in the home straight and crossed the line  seconds ahead of Owen Carleton of Annadale Striders.This was a bucket list moment for Neil as he is a longtime club member and he ran well to achieve it.It tops off a great season so far and leaves him primed for the track season which is his first love. When Aaron McGrady, also EDAC, was third, the stress of the morning was washed away in the joy of having two members on the podium.Mal McGrady of M.B. McGrady and Co Chartered Accountants presented Neil with the Jimmy Murray Memorial Shield at the finish line and the top three received cash prizes.The ladiesrsquo race was almost pre-determined when Emma Mitchell ndash the current , metre track championndash decided to throw her hat in the ring.However, given that she has been targeting half marathon timesand that the pandemic has played havoc with both racing and training, it is hard to gauge where iniduals are form wise.In the end she had a clear win finishing in . with Sinead Murtagh of Newcastle and District AC taking second place in ..Eimear McCracken of City of Lisburn came third in . to complete the podium.Emma was presented with the Joe Quinn Perpetual Trophy for first female and she took the time to say that she was delighted to support the magnicent Jimmyrsquos Ten and that the hospitality from the host club was first class.From an athlete who has raced at top level all over the world, it was praise indeed.Two shields are presented for club teams in the K and this year Newcastle and District took the honours in the menrsquos race and East Down AC retained the ladiesrsquo title.It is based on the top four men and the top three women home. There is also a relay event where two people split the K with one runner starting on the line and then passing over a wristband at the changeover point.Their team-mate then heads home to record a joint time. Ollie Robinson and Jacob Crawfordwere the quickest all male team.Holly Scott and Willow Farrington of Scrabo took the all female prize and the mixed title went to mother and son duo Maureen Kelly and James Wright .With the podiums decided the spectators turned their attention to looking for friends and family.The race is a highlight for local runners, many of whom do not belong to a club. This does not mean that they are not well able and plenty of fast times were recorded as the runners flooded in.Some were running to test their pace, some to seethey could run the distance with no speed in mind, others were raising funds or dedicating their run to causes.In short, there were all sorts of reasons and all sorts of runners but they were united in their efforts and the thrill of crossing a line to cheers.The fact that they were then brought to tables laden with food was a big surprise as for so long hospitality has been withdrawn, but with restrictions eased and a bit of careful planning the hosts were able to entertain their guests outside.Even the weather played ball by that stage as the rain had stopped and there were shreds of sunlight to lt the atmosphere.Jimmyrsquos Ten is always a memorable event but the  event will definitely be lodged in peoplersquos minds as the race that went ahead against all odds.EDAC would like to pay tribute to their full list of sponsors McMahon People Solutions, PCG Fitness, MC Dental Laboratories, Duffyrsquos Killough, JS Flooring, Murdock Brothers , P. Gardiner Carpets, Bells Supervalu Crossgar, McDonalds Downpatrick, Gordons Chemists, Plusprint, Wrap and Roll, McVeigh Traffic Management, Soaring Productions and main sponsor M.B. McGrady and Co Chartered Accountants. The financial backing is what makes this race an event.Thanks are also due to the members and even more so to those who are simply friends of the club, who give up their time to make the race happen. The hard graft that they put in cannot be underestimated.Finally, last but not least, there is heartfelt gratitude towards every single runner who signed up.Without runners there is no race. The smiles of the finishers and the kind words of support post race make all the hard work worthwhile. Well done and see you all next year..prettyPhoto

title: Kilmore overrun Grove in league
story: KILMORE Rec kept their promotion hopes on track with an impressive one-sided victory over a physical Grove United outfit at Robert Adams Park on Saturday.An early penalty kick converted by Anton McGrattan and two further second half goals from Eoin McGrattan and Joe McKinney was enough to see The Blues home and dry in bitterly cold yet sunny conditions.The Blues came firing out of the traps from the first whistle with Kilmore striker Joe McKinney the first to try his luck within the opening minutes, although his effort trickled harmlessly into the gloves of Grove number one Michael Davidson.However, it wouldnrsquot be long until the home side opened their account and after six minutes they were awarded the opportunity to do just that.Following a long ball over the top, Kilmore midfielder Eoin McGrattan spun his marker before he was clumsily clattered from behind inside the danger area.The referee had no hesitation in awarding the penalty kick, which Anton McGrattan dispatched confidently by drilling his effort low and hard to the bottom left corner beyond the reach of Davidson.The Bluesrsquo good start continued as they relentlessly pressed the opposition and didnrsquot allow Grove out of their own half.McKinney danced his way past three opposing defenders before his opportunity at goal was thwarted by a wonderfully timed last ditch tackle from Grove defender David McCallen.This wouldnrsquot deter the ever-dangerous Kilmore marksman, who continued to be a thorn in the side of his United counterparts when he battled to win back the ball before laying off team-mate Patrick Grant for a shot at goal.Grantrsquos effort did swing wide of the post but it was an encouraging sign for the Kilmore team, who clearly had their tails up.Man of the match, Barry Walsh, was enjoying the freedom of the middle of the park, as the Kilmore newcomer flung himself into every tackle necessary in order to gain possession for The Blues.Grove were very much stuck in first gear and were being overran in essentially every area of the park. Kilmore were dealt a blow when Grant came off second best in a crunching tackle with Grove defender Adam McKnight, leading to The Bluesrsquo defender to be substituted on  minutes.However, the silver lining for the hosts came in the form of substitute Joshua Smyth, who made an immediate impact when he entered the fray.Smyth quickly gained possession and whipped in a fast-paced cross to the head of incoming team-mate John McCarthy, whose effort was stunningly saved from point blank range by the reaction of Davidson in the Grove goals.This garnered applause from the sizeable home crowd, who had turned out to support their local side.With half an hour played, Kilmore looked to inflict further damage and almost did so following an eye-catching move which was unfortunate not to double the deficit.Smyth was yet again involved as he played a delicate one-two with the back heel of McKinney before his pass inside to the chest of Eoin McGrattan allowed the midfielder to find team-mate Michael Carvill unmarked at the edge of the box.Carvill unleashed an effort towards goal but it was smartly stopped yet again by Grove custodian Davidson, who was quickly becoming his sidersquos top performer.Any hint of a counterattack from the visitors was quickly dealt with by the confident backline of Christopher Magee, Gary Kennedy and captain Jack Larkin, with Magee in particular winning his inidual battle with Grove striker Jake Long time after time.With less than ten minutes to the interval, Carvill played a short free-kick to McCarthy, who swtly passed to Kennedy  yards from goal.After examining his options, the Kilmore defender decided to take a touch forward before firing a long ranged effort with conviction which ultimately crashed onto the post before falling to the feet of skipper Larkin.The Kilmore captain turned his rebound over the bar although his blushes were saved by the offside flag.Despite Grove proving they were a physically strong side ndash as they never shied away from a tackle ndash they failed to garner any substantial chance throughout the opening  minutes.The half ended with Grove midfielder David Johnston picking up a yellow card for a late challenge on Anton McGrattan.The first real opportunity of the second half fell to Kilmorersquos Walsh, who after a pinball of passes, saw his effort from the edge of the box saved.However, just two minutes later and The Blues would double their scoring tally after marksman McKinney latched on to a long ball before squaring his pass to team-mate Eoin McGrattan for an easy tap in.To their credit, Grove were certainly showing more of a presence in the opposing final third, although they were lacking the end product required to trouble the hosts.Kilmore continued to cause problems and goal-scorer Eoin McGrattan almost added another when he once again showed his marker a clean pair of heels and barrelled down on goal.This time his effort struck the side netting as Grove momentarily escaped conceding a third.The home side refused to settle for just two goals and were almost granted a third when McKinneyrsquos whizzing pass across the box marginally escaped the boot of the onrushing McCarthy.Grove managed to manufacture a seldom chance when captain Michael McNerlin struck a first time volley from  yards which required Kilmore lsquokeeper Christopher Turley to spring into action and tip the ball over the crossbar.However, this seemed to ignite the Kilmore flame further and with  minutes to go they registered their third, courtesy of a surging Walsh run which ended in a pass to McKinney inside the box.The Kilmore striker kept his cool and confidently placed his right footed effort into the net to drown out any chance of a dramatic comeback.Eoin McGrattan made way for substitute John Patterson, who almost added to the scoreline when once again McKinney was allowed to play a pass across goal.However, the substitute fluffed his lines and sent his effort over the bar in what was an escape for the now weathered looking Grove outfit.The visitors were gted a consolation goal in the th minute, after substitute David Long was adjudged to be fouled in the area by Kilmore captain Larkin.Grove midfielder Johnston confidently tucked his effort into the top right corner but seconds later the final whistle sounded.Following the match Kilmore goal-scorer, Anton McGrattan, gave his thoughts on his sidersquos performance.ldquoI thought we controlled the game, he said.ldquoWe could have gotten two or three goals before half-time but we didnrsquot panic.ldquoWe will just take it one game at a time now, we had a setback against Dromara Village a couple of weeks ago but we have now won two on the bounce.He added: ldquoThere is a massive week ahead, we travel to Rosario for a big three points.Kilmore Rec: C Turley, C Magee, P Grant, J Larkin , G Kennedy, B Walsh, J McCarthy, A McGrattan, J McKinney, M Carvill, E McGrattan.Subs: J Patterson, J Smyth, C Degan.Grove United: M Davidson, A McKnight, J Black, D McCallen, P Montgomery, C Kerr, D Johnston, M McNerlin , D Ellis, J Long, D Erwin.Subs: P McCann, D Long, H Morrow.Yellow card: D Johnston.prettyPhoto

title: Matthew on pressure in  Dancing With The Stars
story: FROM Downpatrick to Rio De Janeiro, Love Island star Matthew MacNabb has tangoed his way into the semi-final of RTEacutersquos Dancing With The Stars.The  year-old will be flying the flag for Downpatrick and Northern Ireland on Sunday when he vies to get through to the final.It was a busy night for Matthew and his dance partner Laura Nolan, with two dances each to complete before the dance-off at the end of the show.They danced a sultry tango to Rio by Duran Duran with judge Arthur Gourounlian commenting after: ldquoMatthew, you brought the passion of Rio to the dance floor tonight.Fellow judge Brian Redmond said: ldquoYou started with intensity, commitment to the movement... its just the face thats missing at this stage, your body brought us on the journey.Loraine Barry, another judge, said: ldquoI like this Matthew, I felt you got yourself in the correct tango position.They scored  from the judges but they picked up extra points in the team dance for their group,Turkish Delights, were victorious.These points, combined with the public, kept Matthew safe from the dance-off.Nicolas Roche became the latest celebrity to exit as he and dance partner Karen Byrne lost out in this weeks dance-off against Ellen Keane and Ervinas Merfeldas.Matthew remained coy over rumours of romance between him and his pro-dance partner Laura, ldquoI havent got a clue about what everyone is on about.However, everyone -mdash including the DWTS judges mdash have noticed a certain spark between him and Laura.ldquoWersquove really grown close, admitted Matthew. ldquoI think with dancing, when yoursquore in this process, itrsquos so intense and yoursquore in each otherrsquos pockets for seven days a week and you become emotionally reliant on the person and vice versa.ldquoIt really is so intense and there is a lot of pressure because yoursquove got the whole nation watching you and yoursquove got the producers and your fellow contestants watching and you donrsquot want to let the down, you donrsquot want to let your family down.He added: ldquoEspecially you donrsquot want to let yourself and your partner down because yoursquove put in all the work, we put in ridiculous work every day. I havenrsquot taken a day off in ten weeks.Matthew revealed he has met Laurarsquos parents and that he was planning what he called ldquoa two-person trip once the show comes to an end.When askedhe ever expected to get to the quarter-final of the show, he said, "Itrsquos amazing to get this far. I had no expectation coming into it."I was never a performer, never danced in my le so it was a whole new world. Going into the show Irsquom rsquo " so I never expected myself to be a good dancer, Irsquom not saying Irsquom a good dancer now but Irsquove definitely improved leaps and bounds since I started.ldquoIrsquom really buzzing at how far Irsquove progressed and hopefully Irsquoll keep that going and improve further from here.He said that he has found the physical demands of dance quite challenging and that his body is breaking down now.ldquoItrsquos constant because yoursquore twisting your body in new ways. Irsquove definitely got an emotional connection and itrsquos something Irsquoll keep up after the show is over, added Matthew.Check out Matthewrsquos progress on Dancing with the Stars this Sunday at .pm on RTEacute One..prettyPhoto

title: Much respected  GP set to retire
story: AFTER almost  years in practice, Dr Alison Smith is retiring next week as a GP in Dundrum and Clough.Health Minister Robin Swann paid a tribute to Dr Smith on a visit last week to the busy Clough surgery of the Dundrum and Clough Family Practice.Mr Swann met Dr Smith and her colleagues, who serve more than , patients in the South Down area.Dr Smith, who lives with her husband Tim in Newcastle, has specialist interests in womenrsquos health, diabetes, learning disability and care for the elderly.Mr Swann said: ldquoDr Smith and her colleagues have been at the forefront of innovations, in particular the implementation of the Multi-Disciplinary Teammodel in the Down Federation.ldquoThe recent extension to the premises here at Clough has been part of the roll-out of that initiative. The practice has recognised both the need for change, and the opportunity that new ways of working provides to improve the quality of care which it can offer to its patients.ldquoShe is an outstanding example of the dedication and professionalism of our GP services.The minister also thanked all of the practice staff or their ldquotireless and ongoing treatment, care and support that they provide to patients, particularly over the past two years.He added: ldquoI know it has not been easy. This has been an incredibly stressful and anxious time for so many of our population and no less so for our GP workforce and their teams who have been in the vanguard of our response to Covid.South Down UUP councillors Jill Macauley and Alan Lewis also paid tribute to Dr Smith.ldquoAlison has served the community of Clough and Dundrum with such attention and dedication over the years, and we have no doubt that her presence will be missed in the local surgeries, their statement said.ldquoWe thank our party colleague and Health Minister Robin Swann MLA for taking the time to call with Alison and all the staff at Clough Health Centre to acknowledge her retirement, as well as seeing around their impressive state of the art facilities.Dr Smith and her husband moved to the Newcastle area in  when he got a job at the YMCA.Originally from Edinburgh and having qualied at Edinburgh University, Dr Smith spent a short time working on the surgical ward of Downe Hospital with Mr Crawford Bell, consultant surgeon.She then worked part-time with Dr Edith Cunningham in Killyleagh and Dr John Kyle in Newcastle before joining the Dundrum and Clough Family Practice as a partner with Dr Kieran Walshe and Dr Alex Greer in . She replaced Dr Ronald Hamilton.Dr Smith said that while she is looking forward to having some time to spend with her family and to travel, she will greatly miss her patients and all the practice staff.ldquoItrsquos been a very exciting, go-ahead practice to be part of and our list has more than doubled since I joined, she said.ldquoItrsquos a lovely team to work with and I will miss all my colleagues and staff terribly after I go, particularly after Covid when our le was so restricted at home.ldquoThe last two years have been quite bizarre in many ways the team has really come together. This is history that we have actually been living and working through which has been good to have been part of that. But I definitely feel ready to move on and itrsquos time for new doctors to be in the practice.She said it was the speed of change that the practice had to contend with at the beginning of the lockdown that proved challenging.ldquoThere is always change in general practice and some of it is not easy but having to work safely through the pandemic while providing a service to our patients was challenging but I think we managed to do that.Dr Smith, who has three adult children mdash Alistair, Sandy and Corinne mdash added that it has been quite emotional for her saying goodbye to her patients over the last few weeks.ldquoThey are like old friends and it was good to be part of their lives. Itrsquos a privilege to be helping people at some of their worst times of their lives.She and her husband are looking forward in several weeks time to welcoming Corinne home from the US for the first since the pandemic.Dr Smith intends to continue to remain on the board of two local charities, MyMy in Newcastle and RIOT in Dundrum..prettyPhoto

title: Patrick Kielty’s love for Northern Ireland
story: PATRICK Kielty has talked about his le, his loves, his passion for Northern Ireland and growing up in Dundrum.Patrick was interviewed by Gerry Kelly last Wednesday night as part of the lsquoIn Conversationrsquo series at the Saint Patrick Centre.He also revealed his thoughts on fatherhood, Brexit and the peace process.Reflecting on his childhood, Patrick recalled the terrible news of the murder of his father, Jack, and how looking back it seemed odd that there wasone bus for one community to go to school and another for the other.ldquoBrexit really was a wake-up call for me, he said and outlined his determination to find common ground. ldquoWeird and wonderful things happen when you decide to share.Patrick also described how he had jumped on a plane after a late night telephone call to his now-we Cat Deely and surprised her the next day in Los Angeles for her birthday lunch.ldquoThe taxi driver from the airport turned to me and said lsquoDo you want me to wait for you rsquo.Even after almost ten years of marriage he said he couldnt believe his luck and joked that being on the red carpet with his we, who is so successful in America, sometimes made people think ldquohes someone sponsored by a charity tagging along.The St Patrickrsquos Choral Society, who are celebrating their th anniversary this year, sang at the sold-out event mdash their first public engagement in over two years.St Patrickrsquos Grammar School student Eva Rowan, who hasjust won the BBC School Young Soloist of the Year competition, performed as part of the evening.The next in the series of events is a conversation on April  with Richard Moore, who was blinded by a rubber bullet in Derry in .Having forgiven and befriended Charles, the soldier who shot him, he has been celebrated world wide as a peace maker by the like of the Dalai Lama and is often described as the lsquoDerry Lamarsquo.Charles will also be part of the conversation by videolink. Tickets are available now at the Saint Patrick Centre including wine reception.The lsquoIn Conversationrsquo series is sponsored by CosyRoof..prettyPhoto

title: Pop up vaccination clinics
story: DETAILS of a series of pop-up coronavirus vaccination clinics across the district over the coming weeks have been announced.The South Eastern Trust has confirmed that the mobile clinics will be in Newcastle, Dundrum, Downpatrick, Ballynahinch and Saintfield.On Monday and Tuesday of this week, clinics were held in Downpatrick and Castlewellan and continue today in Newcastle and Dundrum.The resortrsquos bowling pavilion is the venue for the pop-up clinic which will be in operation between am and .pm, before staff relocate to Dundrum GAC car park. They will be there between .pm and pm.Vaccinators will be back in Downpatrick this Saturday and Sunday, between .am and .pm and based at the Downshire Hospitalrsquos Great Hall.Next Tuesday, March , the mobile clinic will be at Ballynahinch town square between am and .pm before moving to the Saintfield Community Centre. Vaccinators will be at the Belfast Road facility between .pm and pm.The mobile clinics are part of the continuing Northern Ireland-wide drive to get as many people vaccinated as quickly as possible.Health officials have confirmed that booking is not required for the mobile clinics which are offering jabs for everyone over . First, second, third and booster doses are available.Those attending for vaccination must bring photographic ID or proof of address and where possible a health and care number and proof of previous vaccination..prettyPhoto

title: St Patrick’s Day of fun and music for families
story: ALL roads lead to Downpatrick tomorrow for a host of St Patrickrsquos Day celebrations.For the first time in three years, the town will be a hive of activity, with thousands of people expected for the traditional cross-community festival parade which will feature  participants.The celebrations kick off at noon, with residents invited to make their way to St Patrickrsquos Square to enjoy an array of free activities including face painting, walkabout characters, arts and crafts, balloon modelling and live performances.Performing on stage in the afternoon will be the multi-platinum recording artist Brian Kennedy, folk rock legends, The Logues and Weston Loney plus many more.A new attraction is a family festival village beside the Knocknashinna play park where, from noon, there will be the very best in homegrown talent performing live music and circus skills. There will also be pop-up acts as well as many childrenrsquos activities to keep people of all ages thoroughly entertained.There will also be live music from noon at De Courcey Place in English Street featuring a number of bands and singers, with craft activities for the younger generation.The parade is scheduled to leave the Ardglass Road at .pm and snake its way to the lower Market Street car park. The parade will make its way their via Edward Street, John Street, Irish Street and Market Street.The parade will feature a number of stunning floats based around Irish mythology created by Downpatrick Town Committee and Down Community Arts who have been busily working on them with the help of artists Kieron Black and Leontia Haldenby.The five superbly crafted floats are set to make a major impact and have been created thanks to funding provided by Newry, Mourne and Down Council and the Arts Council of Northern Ireland.All those involved in the initiative hope that the collaboration which made the superb floats possible, will continue for the next few years to create even more stunning pieces of work.They say that this year they are making the most of the opportunity to participate in the first major outdoor event staged in the district since the coronavirus pandemic.Children from a number of Downpatrick primary schools are also involved in the project and itrsquos expected that around  of them dressed in costume will accompany the five floats as the parade makes its way to the town centre.As usual, the patron saint will be at the centre of tomorrowrsquos celebrations which include an Irish mass at St Patrickrsquos Church where the traditional blessing of the shamrock takes place.Saul Church and Down Cathedral also feature heavily in the religious aspects for tomorrowrsquos events.At Saul, there will be a service of Holy Communion at .am where the special guest will be Captain George Newell who will be joined by Bishop David McClay, Dean Henry Hull and other clergy.An hour later, many of this taking part in the service will join together with others from the pilgrimage walk from the historic church to Down Cathedral where the traditional cross-community service and wreath-laying ceremony takes place.The St Patrick Centre is also hosting a number of events while the Pepper Johns Community Centre in Church Avenue will be serving tea and coffee and tasty tray bakes from .am.And for the first time this year, a park and ride service will be in operation between am and pm with visitors able to park their cars at Downpatrick racecourse at the Ballydugan Road and be ferried by bus to the Lower Market Street car park.Full festival programme details are available at https:www.visitmournemountains whats-on st-patricks-festival or visit Facebook @VisitMourne, Twitter @VisitMourne and Instagram @VisitMourne..prettyPhoto

title: St Patrick's day for all
story: THOUSANDS of people are expected in Downpatrick tomorrow for the townrsquos first St Patrickrsquos Day parade in three years.The finishing touches have been put to a packed programme of events, culminating in the spectacular cross-community festival parade which will feature over  dferent groups and around  people, including children from a number of local schools.A wide iety of floats will be on show, including five stunning creations made by Downpatrick Town Committee and Down Community Arts, with the help of creative artists Kieron Black and Leontia Haldenby.The parade mdash which leaves the Downshire Civic Centre at the Ardglass Road at .pm mdash will also include swirling dancers, a cavalcade of community floats, costumed characters and a cavalcade of vintage cars.Prior to the global pandemic, around , visitors flocked to Downpatrick for the annual parade, religious services and festival fringe events.Theof the March  spectacular in the home of the patron saint also provides a much-needed boost for traders with the town centre expected to be thronging with people tomorrow, especially given the encouraging weather conditions.Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairwoman Cathy Mason hopes many people will take the opportunity to make their way to Downpatrick for the first St Patrickrsquos Day parade since  and have an enjoyable family day out in an area where the patron started and ended his ministry.She is delighted that the annual parade will take place once again to provide an opportunity to celebrate the best in home grown talent.ldquoThe Downpatrick parade has grown in stature and spectacle over the years and the line-up this year offers visitors and residents an entertaining day out to enjoy with family and friends, said the chairwoman.Cllr Mason said she was ldquohonoured and privileged to lead the festival parade, which is just one of a number of events for local people and visitors to enjoy tomorrow.ldquoThe weather forecast looks promising and I hope people have an enjoyable day, she added.ldquoTomorrow will be the first time that I will lead the parade which is the first to take place in Downpatrick since , she said.ldquoI think everyone is ready for the parade, with the festival providing an opportunity for people to get out and about again and meet up with friends.ldquoTheof the St Patrickrsquos Day celebrations will also provide a boost for traders who endured a particularly tough time during the pandemic. I hope tomorrowrsquos festivities will bring a lot of le to the town centre.Cllr Mason also hopes that next year there will be a series of events in the lead up to St Patrickrsquos Day to make the most of the patron saintrsquos links with Downpatrick and the wider Lecale area.ldquoTomorrowrsquos parade and the ious other events that are taking place is a good news story, especially for Downpatrick. I would encourage people to come out and enjoy themselves in as safe a way as possible and support local businesses, she said.ldquoThe weather forecast looks promising and I hope people have an enjoyable day..prettyPhoto

title: Welcome opportunity to see Downe%2C says minister
story: STORMONT Health Minister Robin Swann paid a private visit to the Downe Hospital last week.Accompanied by local UUP councillors Alan Lewis and Jill Macauley last Tuesday evening, Mr Swann met a number of staff and South Eastern Trust chief executive Roisin Coulter and the organisationrsquos Director of Hospital Services David Robinson.The health minister chatted with consultants and staff in the hospitalrsquos day procedure unit where cataract surgery and endoscopies are carried out.The cataract service offers co-located diagnostics and treatment facilities where patients can receive pre-assessment, treatment and their post-operative review on-site.Last month, around  pre-assessments and one-stop pre-surgery checks were carried out at the hospital. Operating seven days per week, over  cataract operations were undertaken and over  post-operative reviews were also delivered.Mr Swann described his visit as a ldquovery welcome opportunity to see the excellent facilities at the Downe Hospital and to meet the dedicated teams who have shown such tremendous commitment to patient care right through the pandemic.ldquoStaff have had to adapt at pace to new ways of working and I want to commend them for their hard work and innovative approaches to maintaining and rebuilding services, he said.While at the Struell Road hospital, Mr Swann also visited the urgent care centre which in October  at the height of the coronavirus pandemic became the first ldquophone first consultant-led service in the South Eastern Trust area.Dr Catherine Bell explained to the Minister that on average,  people use the service every month, ensuring they receive the right care, in the right place, first time.Health trust officials say that prior to the introduction of the ldquopone first service, around  patients per week had to be transferred to the Ulster Hospital. That figure has now reduced to two.Mr Swann was also informed that in January this year, % of patients were seen in the urgent care centre within two hours of arriving, % of patients seen within four hours.The health minister also heard details about the hospitalrsquos busy minor injuries unit which operates every weekend. Before leaving, Mr Swann took the opportunity to visit and chat to patients in Ward .The health trust chief executive said she was delighted that Mr Swann took time out of his ldquohectic schedule to meet staff and patients.Mrs Coulter added: ldquoThe hospital plays a pivotal role in the Trustrsquos hospital network and provides vital services for the community. It was great that the Minister was able to see that for himself..prettyPhoto

title: landmark libel win news letter article was slammed as inaccurate and irresponsible but was true
story: Sir Jeffrey Donaldson and Paul Givan to stand for DUP in Lagan Valley Assembly election   Joe Biden tells St Patrick’s Day gathering: I may be Irish but I’m not stupidNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsNationalLandmark libel win: News Letter article was slammed as ‘inaccurate and irresponsible’... but was trueA landmark legal case against the News Letter began on July , , with an article headlined ‘McKee book to fund ex-bomber’s group’, written by this reporter.By Adam KulaSaturday, th March , : amUpdated Saturday, th March , : am  "       "  The late Jackie Nicholl with a picture of his -month-old son Colin, who was killed by an IRA blast in Belfast in . McClenaghan had befriended Mr Nicholl, who sat alongside him on the Victims and Survivors Forum, without Mr Nicholl knowing his past. Yet McClenaghan was described as "open and honest" in a press release attacking the News LetterIf it had succeeded, it would have had a revolutionary effect on news journalism in the British Isles, sharply restricting the scope of what could be reported.The case is explained in full in the link below, but in one sentence, here’s what our article had revealed: A posthumous book written by a fatal victim of republican paramilitaries , about two fatal victims of republican paramilitaries , was going to financially benefit an outfit called Paper Trail, one of whose trustees wasan unrepentant former republican bomber .   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.On July  a letter arrived announcing the News Letter might be sued for libel .And on the same day a y press release was issued by Excalibur Press, the publisher of Ms McKee’s posthumous book, excoriating this reporter personally and dubbing the article “inaccurate” and “absolutely irresponsible”.In it, Paper Trail chairman Niall Ó’Murchú said: “This cynical attempt by the News Letter to portray Paper Trail as an ‘ex-IRA bomber’s group’ is a misrepresentation and is as damaging as it is offensive.”Except it wasn’t a misrepresentation.And far from the News Letter having libelled anyone, our lawyers believed that -anything - we may in fact have a valid libel action ourselves over the press releasewe wanted to pursue it .The press release claimed that McClenaghan had been “open and honest about his past”.The extent of this can be easily tested.McClenaghan had befriended a man called Jackie Nicholl, who sat alongside him on the Victims and Survivors Forum.Mr Nicholl’s -month-old son Colin had been killed by an IRA blast in Belfast in , and he had no idea about McClenaghan’s past as a bomber.Once the the news was broken to him in , he quit the forum in disgust .So much for McClenaghan being “open and honest”.Thanks to those who supported us in this court case, and thanks to you for reading.Landmark libel win: Paper Trail case against News Letter collapses with plaintfs paying towards costs——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. While I have your attention, I also have an important request to make of you.With the coronavirus lockdowns having had a major impact on many of our advertisers — and consequently the revenue we receive — we are more reliant than ever on you taking out a digital subscription.Subscribe to newsletter and enjoy unlimited access to the best Northern Ireland and UK news and information online and on our app. With a digital subscription, you canthan  articles, see fewer ads, enjoy faster load times, and get access to exclusive newsletters and content. Visit https:www.newsletter subscriptionsnow to sign up.Our journalism costs money and we rely on advertising, print and digital revenues to help to support them. By supporting us, we are able to support you in providing trusted, fact-checked content for this website.Ben Lowry, Editor

title: lord empey is right about the dup but the uup also has questions to answer
story: Sir Jeffrey Donaldson and Paul Givan to stand for DUP in Lagan Valley Assembly election   Joe Biden tells St Patrick’s Day gathering: I may be Irish but I’m not stupidNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionLord Empey is right about the DUP but the UUP also has questions to answerA letter from Tom Ferguson:By The NewsroomSaturday, th March , : am  "       "  Letter to the editorI read Lord Empey’s reply Unionists will pay for DUP change to first minister rules,’ March , see link below to my letter  with interest. I agree with his analysis of the damage done by the DUP changes at St Andrew’s to the selection of a first minister. It is hard to escape the conclusion that the changing of the selection of first minister from the largest grouping to the largest party was anDUP ploy to blackmail unionists into voting for them to stop a Sinn Fein first minister.However, the rest of Lord Empey’s letter implies that his party is prepared to work the Belfast Agreement, even inside these strictures imposed by DUP at St Andrew’s. This deal promised unionists that no constitutional change could be made in Northern Ireland’s status without consent. The NI Protocol has done just that and allowed the EU and its local poodle, the Irish Republic, to make laws over our heads.    " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.The imposition of the protocol has shown the Belfast Agreement to be a sham. It is time unionists united around the removal of both.Will all unionists, including the UUP, combine to secure our place in the British Union, or will the lure of jobs and local power be sufficient for some so-called unionist parties to accept EU Irish rule Tom Ferguson, BallymoneyLetter: Unionists will pay for the DUP Sinn Fein change to the mechanism for choosing first minister——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website.
